intro: Cyrtandra paludosa var. paludosa, commonly known as the marsh cyrtandra, is a herbaceous plant native to tropical regions of Asia and the Pacific. It typically grows in moist or wetland habitats, such as swamps and marshes, where it thrives in humid, nutrient-rich environments. The plant features lance-shaped leaves with a smooth or slightly hairy surface, and it produces small, tubular flowers that are often pink or white in color. Cyrtandra paludosa var. paludosa is part of the Gesneriaceae family, which includes many ornamental and ecologically significant species. Its botanical characteristics make it an important component of wetland ecosystems, supporting various pollinators and contributing to local biodiversity.
